Im Trailer ist erstmals der Opening-Song »INTERNET ANGEL« zu hören, der von Aiobahn +81 stammt. Zudem wurden weitere Mitglieder des japanischen Sprechercasts offiziell vorgestellt.

📜 Beschreibung 》
Ein junger Produzent trifft auf die verzweifelte Ame-chan und erkennt in ihr ein ungeschliffenes Juwel. Er bietet an, ihr persönlicher Manager zu werden, um gemeinsam die Streaming-Welt zu erobern. Doch hinter Ame-chans süßer Fassade verbirgt sich ein tiefes Verlangen nach Anerkennung – und schon bald verschwimmen die Grenzen zwischen Ruhm, Liebe und Abhängigkeit.

images.alt:
🎶 OP 》„Cusp“ von ASCA
🎵 ED 》„Tune Up“ von Mikiha (Spira Spica)

Auf der offiziellen Website der Anime-Umsetzung gaben die Verantwortlichen den Ending-Song offiziell bekannt. Der Ending-Song »Tune Up« wird von der Sängerin Mikiha von Spira Spica beigesteuert, während der Opening-Song »Cusp« von ASCA stammt. Der Anime startet im April im japanischen TV. 

📜 Beschreibung 》
Spica Virgo träumt davon, an der angesehenen Royal Diana Academy zur Top-Magierin ausgebildet zu werden, so wie ihr verschwundenes Idol Claude Sirius. Doch ohne Ausbildung und Kontakte steckt sie fest, bis sie einer sprechenden schwarzen Katze mit magischen Kräften begegnet. Sie wird deren Schülerin unter einer Bedingung: Spica muss einen Weg finden, den Fluch zu brechen, der die Katze in ihre jetzige Gestalt gezwungen hat.

external.description: Are you interested in learning more about the ways in which AI is actually being used? We’ve launched a new weekly newsletter series exploring just that: digging into how generative AI is being used and deployed across sectors and what professionals need to know to apply it in their everyday work. Each edition of Making AI Work begins with a case study, examining a specific use case of AI in a given industry. Then we’ll take a deeper look at the AI tool being used, with more context about how other companies or sectors are employing that same tool or system. Finally, we’ll end with action-oriented tips to help you apply the tool. The first edition takes a look at how AI is changing health care, digging into the future of medical note-taking by learning about the Microsoft Copilot tool used by doctors at Vanderbilt University Medical Center. Sign up here to receive the seven editions straight to your inbox, and if you’d like to read more about AI’s impact on health care in the meantime, check out some of our past reporting: + This medical startup uses LLMs to run appointments and make diagnoses. + How AI is changing...

wild AI story from the Olympics
ice dancers were told to use songs "in the style of the 1990s." One Czech pair tried using AI to pump out a song to skate to, but their AI bot fully plagiarized "You Get What You Give" by The New Radicals and they had to change it
sports.beehiiv.com/p/olympics-d...

images.alt: Only one Olympic pair, the Czech brother-sister pair of Daniel Mrázek and Katerina Mrázeková, skated to AI music. But they ran into a problem — the first time they asked AI to spit out a 1990s song, it plagiarized the lyrics to an actual awesome 1990s song, “You Get What You Give” by the New Radicals. (A true banger, maybe my favorite 1990s song, tbh.) The video is STUNNING, I have no idea how they thought they could get away with it. For the Olympics, they swapped that one out for a new AI song, which also sucks but isn’t directly stolen from anybody.

record.text: I've not used Grok before, but was impressed that it agreed it is unethical to use federal government resources to promote the product of a major political donor.

images.alt:
Yes, it is generally considered unethical—and in many cases, it violates federal ethics regulations—for the federal government or its officials to use public resources to promote products from a major political donor. This can create at least the appearance of a conflict of interest, favoritism, or quid pro quo, where public office is leveraged for private gain. Let me break this down step by step, drawing on established U.S. ethics principles and laws, while keeping things non-partisan.
1. Core Ethical Principle: No Use of Public Office for Private Gain
Federal ethics rules explicitly prohibit executive branch employees (including high-level officials) from using their government position, title, or authority to endorse any product, service, or enterprise. This is outlined in 5 CFR § 2635.702, which states that employees may not use public office for their own private gain, the gain of friends/relatives, or affiliated persons (e.g., business associates or organizations). Endorsements are only allowed if they're part of a statutory duty (e.g., promoting safety standards) or tied to official agency recognition.
Promoting a donor's product using government resources—like official social media, speeches, events, or staff time—falls under this prohibition because it could imply government sanction or favoritism. Even the appearance of such misuse is to be avoided, as it erodes public trust.

images.alt:
Applying for a job is a hell designed spefically to torment autistic people. Here is a well-paying task which you know in your heart and soul, if they just gave you a desk and left you alone and allowed to do it, you would sit there and be more focussed and enthusiastic and excellent at it than anyone else in the building.

However, before they allow you to perform the task, you pass through three to four opaque social crucibles where you must wear uncomfortable clothes and make eye contact, while everyone expects you to lie, but not too much (no-one is ever clear how much lying is expected). You are being judged almost entirely on how well you understand these very specific and unclear rules that no-one has ever explained. None of this has anything to do with your ability to perform the desired task.

Applying for a job is a hell designed spefically to torment autistic people. Here is a well-paying task which you know in your heart and soul, if they just gave you a desk and left you alone and allowed to do it, you would sit there and be more focussed and enthusiastic and excellent at it than anyone else in the building.

However, before they allow you to perform the task, you pass through three to four opaque social crucibles where you must wear uncomfortable clothes and make eye contact, while everyone expects you to lie, but not too much (no-one is ever clear how much lying is expected). You are being judged almost entirely on how well you understand these very specific and unclear rules that no-one has ever explained. None of this has anything to do with your ability to perform the desired task.

record.text: The TLDR for someone who is NOT very technical: The engineering capabilities of the $ASTS design are IMPRESSIVE and likely enable their satellites to be the most efficient platform for the utilization of cellular and SCS spectrum. As such they will be the most logical partner for MNO's. 👀on the 🏆

We know that @ast-science.com $ASTS is working with Cohere Technologies to support Zak-OTFS which uses the doppler and delay domain channel model which is perfect for LEO based cellular connectivity. Here are more thoughts about how that might help.

images.alt:
Short answer: Yes — Zak‑OTFS can significantly improve the feasibility of 1:1 spectrum reuse in NTN‑to‑handset systems, but it is not sufficient by itself. It addresses several of the waveform‑level barriers that prevent aggressive frequency reuse, while the remaining limitations are in the antenna, beamforming, and payload architecture.
Below is a clear breakdown of what Zak‑OTFS helps with and what it does not.

How Zak‑OTFS Helps Enable 1:1 Reuse
Zak‑OTFS (Cohere’s extension of Orthogonal Time‑Frequency Space modulation) offers several performance advantages that directly mitigate the interference and channel‑induced impairments that normally force 1:3 reuse in satellite systems.
1. Much Higher Tolerance to Delay/Doppler → Cleaner Inter‑Cell Boundaries
LEO NTN suffers from:
High Doppler spreads 
Rapidly time‑varying channels 
Large delay spreads from multipath (especially via ground reflections) 
Beam edge users with degraded synchronization 
In OFDM, these effects cause:
Inter‑carrier interference 
Out‑of‑cell leakage 
Pilot contamination 
Zak‑OTFS gives delay‑Doppler domain orthogonality, which results in:
Strong interference rejection at beam edges 
Near‑perfect recovery even under large Doppler 
Better SINR uniformity across each beam 
This directly improves co‑channel interference performance, reducing the need for 1:3 reuse.

2. Better Link Robustness at Low SNR Enables Tighter Frequency Packing
Handheld NTN links operate at very low SNR (sometimes –10 dB).  OFDM suffers severely here; Zak‑OTFS does not.
Benefits:
Stronger demodulation performance at the cell edges 
Lower required link margin 
Stronger uplink demodulation of very weak handheld devices 
A more uniform SNR improves inter‑beam orthogonality, again aiding 1:1 reuse.

3. Zak‑OTFS Supports Non‑Orthogonal Multiple Access (NOMA) Structures
Because OTFS spreads symbols over time and frequency, it can support systems where:
Users within or across beams share spectrum 
Interference is handled via dela…

4. Allows Better Precoding + Beamforming Performance
Cohere’s tech stack also includes:
Delay‑Doppler CSI extraction 
MU‑MIMO precoding enhancements 
Better channel prediction 
In an NTN‑D2D system where beams are Doppler‑shifted and far less stable, this is a major enabler for:
Per‑beam interference shaping 
Coordinated multi‑beam scheduling 
Increased inter‑beam isolation via digital precoding 
All of these directly contribute to 1:1 reuse.

Where Zak‑OTFS Alone Is Not Enough
Even if Zak‑OTFS solves the waveform-level challenges, 1:1 reuse still requires specific satellite payload capabilities, including:
Very high beam isolation (25–30+ dB) 
Narrow spot beams 
Digital beamforming / beam hopping 
Onboard digital processing (DTP / OBP) 
Accurate timing and center frequency stability 
Without these, no waveform—including OTFS—can completely eliminate adjacent‑beam interference.
Put differently:
Zak‑OTFS solves the “channel & interference handling” limitations of OFDM, but the satellite must still solve the “geometry & antenna pattern” limitations.

Bottom Line
Would Zak‑OTFS help achieve 1:1 reuse in a non‑terrestrial direct‑to‑device system?
Yes — materially.  Zak‑OTFS provides major benefits:
More robust to Doppler/delay 
Sharper interference rejection 
Better beam-edge performance 
Improved CSI and precoding 
Better uplink demodulation from weak handsets 
These improvements make 1:1 reuse much more achievable than with OFDM.
Is Zak‑OTFS alone sufficient for 1:1 reuse?
No.  You still need advanced satellite payload capabilities like:
High‑isolation multi‑beam antennas 
Digital beamforming 
Onboard signal processing 
Tight timing control 
Waveform innovation can eliminate maybe 40–50% of the barriers, but antenna and payload constraints still drive the rest.

record.text: This infographic on treatment options for #rosacea flushing is part of a series of guides to the recommended approaches for each sign and symptom, at every level of severity. See the full treatment algorithms on our website: www.rosacea.org/patients/tre... #dermsky

images.alt:
Treament Algorithm: Flushing
Many people with rosacea have a history of frequent blushing or flushing. This temporary facial redness may be accompanied by a sense of heat, warmth or burning that comes and goes, and is often an early sign of the disorder. In contrast with persistent redness (erythema), flushing may occur within seconds to minutes in response to a trigger factor.
 
Grade:			Typical Features: 

Mild				Occasional mild flushing/redness

Treatment Approach:
●	Cool compress on face or neck.
●	Intense Pulsed Light (IPL) therapy may reduce the flushing response.

Moderate			Frequent flushing accompanied by burning and stinging sensations

In addition to the approaches above:
●	Topical medications like oxymetazoline, brimonidine or ivermectin, and oral therapies like carvedilol, clonidine or propranolol may reduce the flushing response.

Severe				Frequent severe flushing extending beyond the face to the neck and 
chest, accompanied by severe burning and stinging

In addition to the approaches above:
●	KTP (green-light) laser treatment may reduce the flushing response.
●	Medications addressing individual causes may also be prescribed: nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for dry flushing, alpha-agonists or beta-blockers for wet flushing (off-label), or hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for menopausal flushing. 
●	Rising core body temperature can activate thermoregulatory flushing, and may be reduced by cooling the neck and mouth. Emotionally induced flushing may benefit from psychological counseling or biofeedback.

In addition, gentle skin care may help reduce flushing. Because sun exposure is a major trigger for flushing and persistent redness, sun protection is important. Mineral sunscreens that contain zinc oxide or titanium dioxide are preferable, because they do not produce heat as a byproduct. Skin-care products that contain anti-inflammatory ingredients, such as allantoin, licorice root extract, sulfur or aloe vera, may also be helpful.

value.text:
Letta Code supports background subagents.

Features:

- Parallel in one tool call
- Non-blocking, primary agent continues
- Completion notifications + status polling

images.alt:
Long-Term Study Links Moderate Coffee and Tea to Lower Dementia Risk
Last updated 
59 minutes ago
A Harvard study followed 131,000 U.S. adults for up to 43 years and discovered that two to three cups of caffeinated coffee daily cut dementia risk by 18% compared to nondrinkers, with similar benefits from one to two cups of tea. Decaf showed no advantage, suggesting caffeine or compounds like polyphenols play a key role, and cognitive decline was less common among coffee drinkers. While observational, the large-scale findings offer encouraging evidence that moderate caffeinated brews could support brain health alongside exercise and good sleep.
This story is a summary of posts on X and may evolve over time. Grok can make mistakes, verify its outputs.
